what: Create a Soil Health Report Project
title: New Template Project
text: assume working RStudio Desktop. workflow tested IDEs Visual Studio Code. two ways create RStudio project. Option 1. Open RStudio > File > New Project > "Soil Health Quarto Report" RStudio Project Wizard Soil Health Quarto Report selected Option 2. console, run: following print console: Output running soils::create_soils() RStudio console. usethis::create_project() prints steps creating new project directory.
code: soils::create_soils(path = "path/to/project")

title: New Template Project
text: options create launch new RStudio project : inst folder containing Quarto template, child documents, example data, images, style resources. Read Soil Health Report Article information components recommended workflow modifying . R folder R scripts source code soils functions customization. Note: decide change functions, need update _producerReport.qmd. example, change make_ft() function tables.R file, add source(::("R/tables.R") top {r setup} chunk. Read Visualization Functions Article details.
code: ├── inst │   ├── _producerReport.qmd │   ├── 01_project_summary.qmd │   ├── 02_soil_health_background.qmd │   ├── 03_physical_measurements.qmd │   ├── 04_biological_measurements.qmd │   ├── 05_chemical_measurements.qmd │   ├── 06_looking_forward.qmd │   ├── 07_acknowledgement.qmd │   ├── extdata │   │   ├── dataDictionary.csv │   │   ├── dfPlot.csv │   │   ├── dfTexture.csv │   │   ├── exampleData.csv │   │   ├── headers.RDS │   │   └── tables.RDS │   ├── images │   │   ├── biological.png │   │   ├── chemical.png │   │   ├── logo.png │   │   └── physical.png │   ├── resources │   │   ├── styles.css │   │   └── word-template.docx └── R     ├── data_wrangling.R     ├── helpers.R     ├── map.R     ├── plots.R     ├── render.R     └── tables.R

title: New Template Project
text: used RStudio IDE create project, main Quarto template _producerReport.qmd automatically open new project session. used soils::create_soils(), need open inst folder access file Files pane. RStudio Files pane showing .qmd files resources inside project > inst folder _producerReport.qmd open, click Render button top file generate either HTML MS Word report. RStudio Quarto render button dropdown HTML MS Word renders report inst directory file name match input .qmd name. fastest way render reports great iterating content style. ’re ready render reports producers project, use render_producer_report() function. year producer ID incorporated file name (ex. 2023_WUY05_Report.html). can specify output directory want reports stored. iterate producer ID year render reports , use purrr::walk(). See example R code read article Soil Health Reports details.

title: Visualize and Report Soil Health Data
text: report template uses Quarto, next-generation version R Markdown. version RStudio must least v2022.07 editing previewing Quarto documents. Though strongly recommended use latest release RStudio. render .docx files, must Microsoft Word installed.

title: Visualize and Report Soil Health Data
text: Read New Template Project Article detailed -. view vignette within RStudio, run command vignette("project", "soils").

title: Visualize and Report Soil Health Data
text: package can generate static .docx reports interactive .html reports. Read article Soil Health Reports detailed -check example reports. view vignette within RStudio, run command vignette("report", "soils"). First page example .docx report beginning example .html report

title: Visualize and Report Soil Health Data
text: Read Visualization Functions Article details. view vignette within RStudio, run command vignette("functions", "soils").

title: Visualize and Report Soil Health Data
text: Default fonts colors within soils come Washington Soil Health Initiative (WaSHI) branding package washi. allows create beautiful plots, tables, reports box. can customize fonts colors match branding modifying soils functions, style sheets, report templates. install, import, register default fonts (Lato headings, Poppins body text), follow instructions

title: Visualize and Report Soil Health Data

Soil Health Report Template used generate report developed Washington State Department Agriculture Washington State University (WSU) part Washington Soil Health Initiative. title: Make facetted strip plot interactive with plotly — make_plotly
text: df Dataframe containing columns: category, abbr_unit, unit, dummy, sampleLabel. font_family Font family use throughout plot. Defaults "Poppins". primary_color Color producer's sample points Defaults WaSHI green. secondary_color Color sample points "crop" "county" values category column. Defaults WaSHI gray. other_color Color sample points "fields" value category column. Defaults WaSHI tan. primary_accent_color Color facet strip background. Defaults WaSHI blue.

title: Make facetted strip plot interactive with plotly — make_plotly
code: # For Poppins font, must have it installed and registered in R with # the `{extrafont}` package. library(extrafont) #> Registering fonts with R  # Read in wrangled plot data. # See `data_wrangling.R` for processing steps. path <- soils_example("dfplot.csv") df <- read.csv(path, encoding = "UTF-8") #> Warning: file("") only supports open = "w+" and open = "w+b": using the former #> Error in read.table(file = file, header = header, sep = sep, quote = quote,     dec = dec, fill = fill, comment.char = comment.char, ...): no lines available in input  # The data structure necessary to render the df triangle dplyr::slice_sample(df, n = 1, by = category) |>   dplyr::glimpse() #> Error in UseMethod("slice_sample"): no applicable method for 'slice_sample' applied to an object of class "function"  # Make sure class of `category` is `ordered factor` with `Your fields` # at the end so it is plotted on top of the other points. df$category <- factor(   df$category,   levels = c(     "Other fields",     "Same county",     "Same crop",     "Your fields"   ),   ordered = TRUE ) #> Error in df$category: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable  class(df$category) #> Error in df$category: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable  levels(df$category) #> Error in df$category: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable  # Remember this function creates the plot specifically for the Quarto # rendered reports and will not look right outside of the reports.  make_plotly(df) #> Error in df$category: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable

Defaults WaSHI gray. other_color Color sample points "fields" value category column. Defaults WaSHI tan. primary_accent_color Color facet strip background. Defaults WaSHI blue.

title: Make facetted strip plot — make_strip_plot
text: Facetted ggplot2. strip plot

title: Make facetted strip plot — make_strip_plot
code: # For Poppins font, must have it installed and registered in R with # the `{extrafont}` package. library(extrafont)  # Read in wrangled plot data. # See `data_wrangling.R` for processing steps. path <- soils_example("dfplot.csv") df <- read.csv(path, encoding = "UTF-8") #> Warning: file("") only supports open = "w+" and open = "w+b": using the former #> Error in read.table(file = file, header = header, sep = sep, quote = quote,     dec = dec, fill = fill, comment.char = comment.char, ...): no lines available in input  # The data structure necessary to render the df triangle dplyr::slice_sample(df, n = 1, by = category) |>   dplyr::glimpse() #> Error in UseMethod("slice_sample"): no applicable method for 'slice_sample' applied to an object of class "function"  # Make sure class of `category` is `ordered factor` with `Your fields` at the # end so it is dfted on top of the other points. df$category <- factor(   df$category,   levels = c(     "Other fields",     "Same county",     "Same crop",     "Your fields"   ),   ordered = TRUE ) #> Error in df$category: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable  class(df$category) #> Error in df$category: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable  levels(df$category) #> Error in df$category: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable  # Make the plot make_strip_plot(df, output = "static") #> Error in df$category: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable

title: Make a texture triangle — make_texture_triangle
text: data_wrangling.R wrangles data specific structure shown example. Currently, many variables values hard-coded function. future work, hope broaden function's flexibility. See example input data structure must look like.

title: Make a texture triangle — make_texture_triangle
code: make_texture_triangle(   df,   primary_color = washi::washi_pal[["standard"]][["red"]],   secondary_color = washi::washi_pal[["standard"]][["gray"]],   other_color = washi::washi_pal[["standard"]][["tan"]],   font_family = "Poppins" )

title: Make a texture triangle — make_texture_triangle
text: df Data frame containing columns: Sand, Clay, Silt, category primary_color Color producer's sample points Defaults WaSHI green. secondary_color Color sample points "crop" "county" values category column. Defaults WaSHI gray. other_color Color sample points "fields" value category column. Defaults WaSHI tan. font_family Font family use throughout plot. Defaults "Poppins".

title: Make a texture triangle — make_texture_triangle
text: ggplot2 texture triangle.

title: Make a texture triangle — make_texture_triangle
code: # For Poppins font, must have it installed and registered in R with # the `{extrafont}` package. library(extrafont)  # Read in wrangled texture data. # See `data_wrangling.R` for processing steps. path <- soils_example("dfTexture.csv") df <- read.csv(path)  # The data structure necessary to render the df triangle dplyr::slice_sample(df, n = 1, by = category) |>   dplyr::glimpse() #> Rows: 4 #> Columns: 7 #> $ sampleId <chr> "22-REY04-04", "23-DJU01-03", "23-DOK01-01", "23-WUY05-03" #> $ category <chr> "Other fields", "Same county", "Same crop", "Your fields" #> $ Field    <chr> "Field 04", "Field 03", "Field 01", "Field 03" #> $ Texture  <chr> "Loam", "Loamy Sand", "Sandy Loam", "Sandy Loam" #> $ Sand     <int> 39, 84, 64, 64 #> $ Silt     <int> 43, 10, 26, 33 #> $ Clay     <int> 18, 6, 10, 3  # Make sure class of `category` is `ordered factor` with `Your fields` at the # end so it is plotted on top of the other points. df$category <- factor(   df$category,   levels = c(     "Other fields",     "Same county",     "Same crop",     "Your fields"   ),   ordered = TRUE )  class(df$category) #> [1] "ordered" "factor"   levels(df$category) #> [1] "Other fields" "Same county"  "Same crop"    "Your fields"   # Make the plot make_texture_triangle(df) #> Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'ggtern': #>   method           from    #>   grid.draw.ggplot ggplot2 #>   plot.ggplot      ggplot2 #>   print.ggplot     ggplot2

title: Render producer reports — render_producer_report
text: Render _producerReport.qmd .html .docx files. word document outputs opened manually edited ensure report looks good. See vignette("docx", package = "soils") details edits

title: Render producer reports — render_producer_report
code: render_producer_report(producerId, year, output = "html", output_dir = NULL)

title: Render producer reports — render_producer_report
text: producerId Character producerId render report . year Year samples include report. output Target output format. Currently supported options: "html" interactive report. "docx" editable word document. "" rendering supported output formats. output_dir Path directory holds reports. NULL, reports saved project directory.

title: Render producer reports — render_producer_report
code: if (FALSE) { # Render single html report for first producer in data set first_producer <- head(exampleData$producerId, 1) render_producer_report(   first_producer,   year = 2023,   output = "html",   output_dir = paste0(here::here(),"/inst/reports/") )  # Render docx reports for all 2023 producers unique(exampleData$producerId) |>   purrr::walk(     \(producerId) render_producer_report(       producerId,       year = 2023,       output = "docx",       output_dir = paste0(here::here(),"/inst/reports/"),       .progress = TRUE     )   ) }

title: ggplot2::ggsave() with default arguments — save_plot
text: Wrapper ggplot2::ggsave() save plot specified directory default settings .png output dimensions 6" x 4".

title: ggplot2::ggsave() with default arguments — save_plot
code: save_plot(plot, path, device = "png", height = 4, width = 6, units = "in")

title: ggplot2::ggsave() with default arguments — save_plot
text: plot Plot save, defaults last plot displayed. path Path directory save plot . File name determined name plot file extension. device Device use. Can either device function (e.g. png), one "eps", "ps", "tex" (pictex), "pdf", "jpeg", "tiff", "png", "bmp", "svg" "wmf" (windows ). width, height, units Plot size units ("", "cm", "mm", "px"). supplied, uses size current graphics device.

title: ggplot2::ggsave() with default arguments — save_plot
text: Side effects saving plot.

title: ggplot2::ggsave() with default arguments — save_plot
code: library(ggplot2)  plot <- exampleData |>   ggplot(aes(crop)) +   geom_bar() +   coord_flip()  # Create temp file to save plot file <- tempfile()  # Save plot save_plot(plot, path = file)  # Delete plot file unlink(file)
